body: Converted Barn $1,775,000 CONNECTICUT: 55 Cider Mill Lane, Fairfield An 1890 horse barn fully renovated into a three-story residence with five bedrooms, four and a half baths, finished basement, central air, in-ground pool, three-car detached garage and courtyard patio on 1.12 acres. title: ON THE MARKET

body: A quiz for aspiring burglars: You've just stolen $25,000 or so from a church safe during Christmas morning Mass. There is a witness, a man who asked you what you were doing lugging a heavy metal box containing the money to your Lincoln Navigator, the one with the Vermont plates. The crime is a sensation, all over the news. An entire city is
title: Crime During Christmas Mass Proves Far From Perfect

body: OPEN NOW FIRESIDE -- Sam DeMarco is the chef for this restaurant in the Omni Berkshire Place hotel, where he is serving small plates and more substantial dishes of lusty seasonal food, including pork osso buco, skate in brown butter and foie gras popsicles: 21 East 52nd Street, (212) 754-5011. body: The City Council yesterday approved the first major overhaul of the most popular tax break for apartment building developers, adopting a plan intended to induce them to build tens of thousands of apartments for people other than the well-heeled. The changes, which Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg supported and which would go into effect in 2008,
title: IN OVERHAUL, CITY SEEKS TO EXPAND LOWER-COST UNITS

body: There's a certain facial expression, a mix of anguish and unsated desire, that Sonia Gordon knows she will see each time she tells one of her customers that her restaurant has run out of oxtail stew. ''People leave work, and oxtail is on their mind,'' said Ms. Gordon, the owner and the cook at Stir It Up, a West Indian restaurant on Atlantic Avenue
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; Mouths Water For a Treat Turned Scarce

body: The front window of Davisons & Company, a small storefront on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, bears portraits of two men. One is Nissim Isaac David, an Iraqi Jew who fled Iraq in 1946, leaving behind a store in Baghdad to set up an import-export business in New York. The other is his grandson Michael Rakowitz, 33, an artist and, for the last two
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Bittersweet Talismans From a Ravaged Land

body: THE tiny foyer of Isidro Blasco and Sarah Jay's co-op is decorated with oil paintings that form a trail of their former residences. The couple, who have been married for nine years, have moved a lot. There was the Brooklyn rental. The dingy Shanghai hotel room they shared with a rat. The upstate cottage they transformed from creepy to cute. And
title: HABITATS/Jackson Heights, Queens; As Permanent a Home As Any One Can Be

body: To the Editor: ''Spying on Nanny,'' by Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus (Op-Ed, Nov. 19), was certainly accurate about the need for professional resources and guidance for this expanding group of employees. It, however, did not recognize the needs of parents whose primary concern is the welfare of their children. Like the popular nanny cams, the
title: Watching Those Who Watch Your Kids

body: Smith Street in Brooklyn, the center of a restaurant renaissance during the past decade, shows no sign of slowing down. Vietnamese, Italian and French cuisines are among the most recent arrivals. HANCO'S (718) 858-6818; 85 Bergen Street (Smith Street), Boerum Hill; $; Article: 3/8/06. This bright little Vietnamese shop, owned by Hanco Tang, has
title: GOOD EATING/SMITH STREET; Newborns at a Renaissance

body: It was the first of three public hearings on the $4.2 billion Atlantic Yards development, and Umar Jordan, a 51-year-old resident of Bushwick, Brooklyn, strode to the front of the auditorium and offered a vigorous defense of the proposal. ''I'm here to speak for the underprivileged, the people that don't get the opportunity to work, the brothers
title: Perspectives on the Atlantic Yards Development Through the Prism of Race

body: A 34-year-old Queens man was shot and killed early yesterday near a 24-hour diner in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, while four men were stabbed outside a sports bar in a separate fight in Sheepshead Bay, the police and witnesses said. The Queens man, Dallas Gilchrist, was shot about five times around 5 a.m. outside City Lights Diner, at the corner of
title: Fights Leave 1 Man Dead And 5 Injured In Brooklyn

body: Cheryl Kleinman and Ellen Baumwoll have been making elaborately decorated wedding cakes by appointment at their two companies, Cheryl Kleinman Cakes and Bijoux Doux Specialty Cakes, respectively. Now these two have opened an airy little Brooklyn shop, Betty Bakery, named for Betty Van Nostrand, their teacher and mentor. This felicitous
title: FOOD STUFF; Two Cakemakers in One Brooklyn Shop

body: I'VE never hungered for sponge-painted walls or red and white tablecloths or an old Fernet-Branca poster -- design elements that practically croon ''That's Amore'' -- as much as I did at Lunetta, a new spot on Smith Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. Before Adam Shepard, the chef and a partner in the restaurant, introduced Lunetta's Italian menu last
title: $25 AND UNDER; The Vibe, the Herbs, the Pasta

body: Lake-View Tudor $595,000 NEW JERSEY: 57 Oakwood Drive, Wayne A four-bedroom, three-bath Tudor-style home, built on the foundation of a house demolished in 1988. The setting is one street from Lake Packanack and its community clubhouse, and two blocks from a golf course. The house has nice-sized rooms and an attached two-car garage. Donna Staccioli,
title: ON THE MARKET

body: THE bench where 75-year-old Alvaro Fernandez was sitting when he was killed by a runaway van was gone Wednesday, two weeks to the day after the accident at the corner of Atlantic Avenue and Hoyt Street in Boerum Hill. A handmade memorial that had marked the spot was also gone, but a fire alarm box that the van had plowed over after jumping the curb
title: STREET LEVEL/BOERUM HILL; A Freeway Amid the Brownstones

body: A man crossing Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill about 3:50 a.m. yesterday was struck by two vehicles and killed, the police said. The driver of the first vehicle, Dion Gadsen, 26, of Prospect Heights, was charged with driving with a suspended license, and the driver of the second vehicle was not charged, the police said. The identity of the
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies After Being Struck By Two Cars

body: A man whom neighbors called a fixture in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday when a van jumped a curb and slammed into him as he sat in one of his usual spots: a wooden bench outside a popular market. The man was identified by the police as Alvaro Fernandez, 75, of Staten Island. And although he did not live in the neighborhood, those who
title: Crash Sends Van Into Bench, Killing Hoyt Street Mainstay

body: OPENING THIS WEEK LA LUNETTA -- Adam Shepard, below, made a name for himself in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, cooking praiseworthy Japanese-style dishes like ramen with Berkshire pork, hanger steak with tempura onions, and grilled shrimp soba at his restaurant Taku. But customers in the neighborhood considered Taku to be a weekend and special occasion
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: PAUL FORD, a soft-spoken, sturdily built 32-year-old who works as an editor at Harper's Magazine, sometimes describes his commute between his apartment in Gowanus, Brooklyn, and his office on Broadway near Bond Street as feeling ''like a video game, except you can get killed.'' And in fact, watching Mr. Ford weave through the city's traffic-clogged
title: Queasy Rider

body: A group of neighborhood and civic associations will propose a series of changes to Brooklyn's controversial Atlantic Yards real estate development this weekend, taking a new tack in the bitter debate over the project. The effort will diverge markedly from the strategy of other project skeptics, notably Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn, a coalition of
title: Brooklyn Group to Propose Changes to Yards Project

body: BROOKLYN'S enthusiasts will tell you that the borough is like Paris in its long and distinguished literary tradition. And that consummate enthusiast, Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, has even been known to call it ''the new Left Bank.'' Tomorrow Mr. Markowitz's office has organized what he calls the first-ever Brooklyn Book Festival
title: Literary Voice, Brooklyn Accent

body: AT midnight on the evening of Thursday, Aug. 31, WLIB-AM, one of the city's most storied radio stations and one that for years broadcast from the fabled Hotel Theresa in Harlem, ushered in a new era. A staff member cued up a rousing hymn called ''High Praise,'' and with the push of a button, WLIB was now ''Your praise and inspiration station,''
title: URBAN TACTICS; For the Heartbeat of Harlem, a New Amen Chorus

body: The four-way Democratic race for a Congressional seat in Brooklyn intensified yesterday on the busiest campaign day of the New York primary season, as one candidate faced hecklers -- and even a hurtling doughnut -- in a showdown that underscored the racial tensions in that race. The biggest names in state politics also descended on Eastern Parkway
title: Politicians Go on Parade in Brooklyn; Then Some Are Heckled

body: Sex in New York City, as glamorized as it may be, is far from perfect. From East Village cafes to the streets of East Harlem, women recount tales of broken condoms, and nights of drinking that led to bad decisions and unwanted pregnancies. The morning-after pill, or Plan B, which can prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours of unprotected
title: Easier Access To Plan B Pill Evokes Praise, And Concern

body: THE one-day Brooklyn Country Music Festival kicks off on Sept. 9, which raises the inevitable question: There's a country music festival in Brooklyn? Not only that, but fans of honky-tonk, bluegrass and rockabilly don't need to plan a trip around it. There's a spirited country scene every weekend in New York City and, modest though it may be, you'd
title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: HONKY-TONK CITY; Torchbearers of Urban Twang

body: Brooklyn Center for the Urban Environment; (718) 788-8500, extension 208. Sharon Seitz and Stuart Miller, the authors of The Other Islands of New York City: A History and Guide (Countryman Press, 2001), will lead a tour by water taxi to Roosevelt Island, and Randalls, Wards and the Brother islands, on Sunday from 9 a.m. to noon. title: Calendar: New York by Foot and Boat

body: If 1,200 or so high-rise apartments, a hotel and other private buildings occupy about one-tenth of the land reserved for a park project, is it still a park? The city and state are poised to transform a 1.3-mile stretch of derelict docks and warehouses in Brooklyn Heights into a ribbon of recreation. The 85-acre site, which offers breathtaking views
title: Debate Rages on Housing At Planned Brooklyn Park

body: As Andrew Sarno cruised down Fifth Avenue in Park Slope the other morning, children gawked and dog walkers cast puzzled looks in his direction. When Mr. Sarno stopped his tractor at a red light, a large man named Otis Bryant pulled up in a truck next to him. ''I used to drive that when I was 8 years old!'' Mr. Bryant shouted. ''Down in North
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; Green Acres Is Not the Place for Him

body: SANFORD I. WEILL, the former chairman of Citigroup, and his wife, Joan, sold a co-op penthouse last month at 14 East 90th Street to Elizabeth A. Sackler, the arts patron known for her contributions to the Brooklyn Museum. The apartment, which has a large terrace, had an asking price of $10.5 million. Mr. Weill, 73, stepped down as the chairman of
title: BIG DEAL; My Neighbor, My Buyer

body: Attractions Museums and Sites HISTORIC RICHMOND TOWN, Staten Island Historical Society, 441 Clarke Avenue, Richmond Town. Tomorrow at 2 p.m., a lecture about Staten Island's acres of parkland by Thomas Paulo, Staten Island borough commissioner of parks. Fee: $5; students and members of the Staten Island Historical Society, $4. Hours: Wednesdays
title: Spare Times

author: This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: MICHELLE LEWIS had cooked some chickens and had broken the meat into small pieces. Now she was cutting fresh squash, broccoli, cauliflower, carrots and celery into even smaller pieces, which she would briefly boil. She would later mix everything together, along with safflower oil, flaxseed oil, coconut oil, brown rice and hard-boiled eggs and their
title: HOME FRONT; The Latest Dish, for Four-Legged Friends

body: For the last four decades, the predominantly black population of central Brooklyn has been represented in Washington by one of its own, a tradition that dates to the 1968 victory of Shirley Chisholm, the first black woman elected to Congress. But now, in a district whose boundaries were drawn to strengthen black voting power, residents are locked
title: In Shirley Chisholm's Brooklyn, Rancor Over White Candidacy

body: WHEN Charlie Sahadi was growing up in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, in the 1950's, other neighborhood children set up lemonade stands on hot days. Charlie and his brother sold rose- and violet-flavored drinks at the end of their driveway instead. Their great-uncle was Ibrahim Sahadi, who came to New York from the fertile Bekaa Valley in Lebanon, and began
title: SUMMER DRINKS; The World's Cups

body: CARMINE CINCOTTA, 53, was in his usual position at the back of Jim and Andy's, a narrow slip of a produce store on Court Street along the Boerum Hill-Cobble Hill fault line. A folded copy of a newspaper rested on a box of kiwis in front of him, open to the crossword. ''Fielding novel?'' he grunted, eyes peering over the tops of his black spectacles
title: CITY PEOPLE; Family Matters on Court Street

body: IT'S all gone: every diamond ring, every stack of bills and birth certificate. Today, the safe deposit boxes in the subterranean vault of what used to be the Williamsburgh Savings Bank lie empty in haphazard piles on the dusty floor. The massive vault doors, several feet thick, stand open. No calls will ever go out to Mrs. Helen Massone, whose
title: For Brooklyn's Beacon, The Luxe Life

body: AT Ayun Halliday's and Greg Kotis's SoHo wedding on Nov. 4, 1995, their friends and family didn't wonder whether the marriage would last, but they did question how long their artsy, downtown, no-health-insurance, no-safety-net lifestyle would go on. How long could they write plays on the fire escape, drink out of peanut butter jars and live in an
title: STATE OF THE UNIONS; Ayun Halliday and Greg Kotis -- Featured in Vows, Nov. 12, 1995

body: WALKING south from Brooklyn Heights and encountering a new set of dignified brownstones and cheery stroller-pushing residents, the uninitiated visitor could be forgiven for believing that the Heights continues across Atlantic Avenue. Yet as residents of Cobble Hill might tell you, there is a world of difference in their neighborhood's tranquil
title: LIVING IN/Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; A Timeless Neighborhood Grows Even More Popular

body: NOTHING excites a restaurant hound like the special dish that customers will never taste. Maybe it's the fritters a chef fries up only for friends, or the mole the Oaxacan line cooks serve for staff meals. Or maybe it's the McBruschetta. Amid a string of exchanges on an Internet message board for McDonald's employees around the world at
title: Fast-Food Chefs, Having It Their Way

body: An accomplished fund-raiser for New York City's public schools has been picked as the president of the corporation devoted to the reinvention of Governors Island, a $1 gift to the city and state whose future has been mulled over for three years with little to show for the effort. Leslie Koch, chief executive of the Fund for Public Schools, the
title: A New Motivator for Governors Island

body: To the Editor: A student of New York State education financing since the 1972 Fleischmann Report told Gov. Nelson A. Rockefeller that the state was shortchanging its cities, I applaud Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's recently found hard-line stance. That report established that the Legislature had systematically stolen money from cities' shares of
title: Real Estate Taxes And City Schools

author: E-mail: purnick@nytimes.com
body: ANYONE who doubts the importance New Yorkers place on education -- singled out as their top priority in poll after poll -- should see the e-mail messages that poured in after last Thursday's column about the frustrations of parents trying to get their children into ''gifted'' programs on the Upper West Side. ''Why do I have to send my child to an
title: Metro Matters; Schools Strike A Nerve. Parents Yell.

body: The window grate was down last week at American Liberty Bail Bonds, on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, and it looked as if it had been down for a while. The sign out front was intact, but the storefront, across from the vacant Brooklyn House of Detention on the edge of Boerum Hill, was now home to jumbled stacks of chairs, a dusty dryer and a chunk of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Jailhouse Blues? On the Contrary

body: The Brooklyn House of Detention, bounded by Atlantic Avenue and the criminal courts building, is apparently headed into a mixed-use future. Soon, it will house not only inmates and jail cells, but also, in a vision endorsed by the mayor, a 24,000-square-foot strip mall on the street level. The biggest question may now be which businesses the
title: Prisoners Up Above, 'Nifty-Gifties' Down Below

body: By almost any measure, the Brooklyn House of Detention, 10 stories of razor wire and wire-mesh windows in Boerum Hill, is a repellent sight. But, the city reasons, it need not be so. So, to attract people other than criminal suspects to the 760-bed jail, the Correction Department has decided to convert part of the complex into 24,000 square feet of
title: The Brooklyn House of Detention, Seen as a Jail With Retail

body: Just a couple of steps from the culinary melting pot that Smith Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has become, there is Hanco's, a bright little Vietnamese sandwich shop with a counter and a few tables. Hanco Tang, the owner, below, sells the sandwiches, called banh mi, on warm, plump, crusty little baguettes ($4.25). The classic combines spiced
title: FOOD STUFF; From Vietnam to Boerum Hill

body: The number of inmates in New York City jails has been rising faster than correction officials had anticipated, by 9 percent since Jan. 1, leaving the jails at close to their current capacity. It is not clear why it it is happening, but if the trend continues, the City Correction Department will need to reopen the Brooklyn House of Detention,
title: City Inmate Population Up; Brooklyn Jail May Reopen

author: E-mail: thehunt@nytimes.com
body: SOME things you find when you aren't looking. That's what happened to Kate Rope and David Allan. They had no success finding a rental bigger than the one they had, so they gave up. title: THE HUNT; Learning to Live in a (Slightly) Larger Space

title: $25 AND UNDER; Fine-Tuned Flavors of the Caribbean

body: IN the mid-1990's, Chris Piazza would walk the streets of Brooklyn looking for boarded-up carriage houses. ''I'd take down their addresses,'' she said, ''look up the tax records and write to the owners to see if they wanted to sell.'' She didn't hit pay dirt, so she and her husband at the time decided to move from Prospect Heights to Yonkers. It
title: HABITATS/Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; Her Carriage House Is a Stable for Her Art

body: AT 168th Street and Nelson Avenue in the South Bronx, you can look 134 blocks downtown and see the upper third of the Empire State Building pop up unexpectedly like a silvery beacon. So close to Manhattan, and yet so far away. On that corner, though, the consequences of Manhattan's wealth are beginning to be felt. It is the site of the first
title: So Close

body: HAS lifestyle finally toppled location from the top of the real estate lexicon? The Corcoran Group bought a full-page ad this month in New York magazine for a pair of converted condominium buildings it is marketing at Well, that's just the problem. It is hard to figure out where the condos are. The ad features a photo of six leggy women in evening
title: BIG DEAL; The New 'L' Word

body: A 21-year-old Bronx woman was fatally shot early yesterday in front of her apartment building, the police said, and the man wanted for questioning in her death shot and killed himself hours later in Queens. In two unrelated shootings, they said, the body of a 25-year-old man with a gunshot wound to the head was found in Queens, and a 17-year-old
title: Man, Woman and Boy Are Killed in Separate Shootings in City

author: E-mail: haberman@nytimes.com
body: BAD enough that we have hate crime. But now we have to contend with hat crime as well. Let's say that you want to take your baseball cap or fedora (also known as a real hat), paint something on it and sell it on New York streets as artwork. You can't do that. At least you can't do it without first getting a license from the city. Otherwise, you are
title: NYC; Off With Their Hats!

body: IF you want some red wine with dinner at the opulent new restaurant Gilt in Midtown Manhattan, your options typically rise from a minimum of $20 to a maximum of $1,000, with a median of $55 and an average of $246. title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Creeping Up On Diners: Stealth Charges

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: BOERUM HILL; Bittersweet Talismans From a Ravaged Land

body: THE tiny foyer of Isidro Blasco and Sarah Jay's co-op is decorated with oil paintings that form a trail of their former residences. The couple, who have been married for nine years, have moved a lot. There was the Brooklyn rental. The dingy Shanghai hotel room they shared with a rat. The upstate cottage they transformed from creepy to cute. And
title: HABITATS/Jackson Heights, Queens; As Permanent a Home As Any One Can Be

body: To the Editor: ''Spying on Nanny,'' by Emma McLaughlin and Nicola Kraus (Op-Ed, Nov. 19), was certainly accurate about the need for professional resources and guidance for this expanding group of employees. It, however, did not recognize the needs of parents whose primary concern is the welfare of their children. Like the popular nanny cams, the
title: Watching Those Who Watch Your Kids

body: Smith Street in Brooklyn, the center of a restaurant renaissance during the past decade, shows no sign of slowing down. Vietnamese, Italian and French cuisines are among the most recent arrivals. HANCO'S (718) 858-6818; 85 Bergen Street (Smith Street), Boerum Hill; $; Article: 3/8/06. title: GOOD EATING/SMITH STREET; Newborns at a Renaissance

body: It was the first of three public hearings on the $4.2 billion Atlantic Yards development, and Umar Jordan, a 51-year-old resident of Bushwick, Brooklyn, strode to the front of the auditorium and offered a vigorous defense of the proposal. ''I'm here to speak for the underprivileged, the people that don't get the opportunity to work, the brothers
title: Perspectives on the Atlantic Yards Development Through the Prism of Race

body: A 34-year-old Queens man was shot and killed early yesterday near a 24-hour diner in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, while four men were stabbed outside a sports bar in a separate fight in Sheepshead Bay, the police and witnesses said. The Queens man, Dallas Gilchrist, was shot about five times around 5 a.m. outside City Lights Diner, at the corner of
title: Fights Leave 1 Man Dead And 5 Injured In Brooklyn

body: Cheryl Kleinman and Ellen Baumwoll have been making elaborately decorated wedding cakes by appointment at their two companies, Cheryl Kleinman Cakes and Bijoux Doux Specialty Cakes, respectively. Now these two have opened an airy little Brooklyn shop, Betty Bakery, named for Betty Van Nostrand, their teacher and mentor. This felicitous
title: FOOD STUFF; Two Cakemakers in One Brooklyn Shop

body: I'VE never hungered for sponge-painted walls or red and white tablecloths or an old Fernet-Branca poster -- design elements that practically croon ''That's Amore'' -- as much as I did at Lunetta, a new spot on Smith Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn. Before Adam Shepard, the chef and a partner in the restaurant, introduced Lunetta's Italian menu last
title: $25 AND UNDER; The Vibe, the Herbs, the Pasta

body: Lake-View Tudor $595,000 NEW JERSEY: 57 Oakwood Drive, Wayne A four-bedroom, three-bath Tudor-style home, built on the foundation of a house demolished in 1988. The setting is one street from Lake Packanack and its community clubhouse, and two blocks from a golf course. The house has nice-sized rooms and an attached two-car garage. Donna Staccioli,
title: ON THE MARKET

body: THE bench where 75-year-old Alvaro Fernandez was sitting when he was killed by a runaway van was gone Wednesday, two weeks to the day after the accident at the corner of Atlantic Avenue and Hoyt Street in Boerum Hill. A handmade memorial that had marked the spot was also gone, but a fire alarm box that the van had plowed over after jumping the curb
title: STREET LEVEL/BOERUM HILL; A Freeway Amid the Brownstones

body: A man crossing Atlantic Avenue in Boerum Hill about 3:50 a.m. yesterday was struck by two vehicles and killed, the police said. The driver of the first vehicle, Dion Gadsen, 26, of Prospect Heights, was charged with driving with a suspended license, and the driver of the second vehicle was not charged, the police said. The identity of the
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Dies After Being Struck By Two Cars

body: A man whom neighbors called a fixture in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, was killed yesterday when a van jumped a curb and slammed into him as he sat in one of his usual spots: a wooden bench outside a popular market. The man was identified by the police as Alvaro Fernandez, 75, of Staten Island. And although he did not live in the neighborhood, those who
title: Crash Sends Van Into Bench, Killing Hoyt Street Mainstay

body: OPENING THIS WEEK LA LUNETTA -- Adam Shepard, below, made a name for himself in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, cooking praiseworthy Japanese-style dishes like ramen with Berkshire pork, hanger steak with tempura onions, and grilled shrimp soba at his restaurant Taku. But customers in the neighborhood considered Taku to be a weekend and special occasion
title: FOOD STUFF; OFF THE MENU

body: PAUL FORD, a soft-spoken, sturdily built 32-year-old who works as an editor at Harper's Magazine, sometimes describes his commute between his apartment in Gowanus, Brooklyn, and his office on Broadway near Bond Street as feeling ''like a video game, except you can get killed.'' And in fact, watching Mr. Ford weave through the city's traffic-clogged
title: Queasy Rider

body: A group of neighborhood and civic associations will propose a series of changes to Brooklyn's controversial Atlantic Yards real estate development this weekend, taking a new tack in the bitter debate over the project. The effort will diverge markedly from the strategy of other project skeptics, notably Develop Don't Destroy Brooklyn, a coalition of
title: Brooklyn Group to Propose Changes to Yards Project

body: BROOKLYN'S enthusiasts will tell you that the borough is like Paris in its long and distinguished literary tradition. And that consummate enthusiast, Marty Markowitz, the Brooklyn borough president, has even been known to call it ''the new Left Bank.'' Tomorrow Mr. Markowitz's office has organized what he calls the first-ever Brooklyn Book Festival
title: Literary Voice, Brooklyn Accent

body: AT midnight on the evening of Thursday, Aug. 31, WLIB-AM, one of the city's most storied radio stations and one that for years broadcast from the fabled Hotel Theresa in Harlem, ushered in a new era. A staff member cued up a rousing hymn called ''High Praise,'' and with the push of a button, WLIB was now ''Your praise and inspiration station,''
title: URBAN TACTICS; For the Heartbeat of Harlem, a New Amen Chorus

body: The four-way Democratic race for a Congressional seat in Brooklyn intensified yesterday on the busiest campaign day of the New York primary season, as one candidate faced hecklers -- and even a hurtling doughnut -- in a showdown that underscored the racial tensions in that race. The biggest names in state politics also descended on Eastern Parkway
title: Politicians Go on Parade in Brooklyn; Then Some Are Heckled

body: Sex in New York City, as glamorized as it may be, is far from perfect. From East Village cafes to the streets of East Harlem, women recount tales of broken condoms, and nights of drinking that led to bad decisions and unwanted pregnancies. The morning-after pill, or Plan B, which can prevent pregnancy if taken within 72 hours of unprotected
title: Easier Access To Plan B Pill Evokes Praise, And Concern

title: WEEKEND IN NEW YORK: HONKY-TONK CITY; Torchbearers of Urban Twang

body: If 1,200 or so high-rise apartments, a hotel and other private buildings occupy about one-tenth of the land reserved for a park project, is it still a park? The city and state are poised to transform a 1.3-mile stretch of derelict docks and warehouses in Brooklyn Heights into a ribbon of recreation. The 85-acre site, which offers breathtaking views
title: Debate Rages on Housing At Planned Brooklyn Park

body: As Andrew Sarno cruised down Fifth Avenue in Park Slope the other morning, children gawked and dog walkers cast puzzled looks in his direction. When Mr. Sarno stopped his tractor at a red light, a large man named Otis Bryant pulled up in a truck next to him. ''I used to drive that when I was 8 years old!'' Mr. Bryant shouted. ''Down in North
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: PARK SLOPE; Green Acres Is Not the Place for Him

body: SANFORD I. WEILL, the former chairman of Citigroup, and his wife, Joan, sold a co-op penthouse last month at 14 East 90th Street to Elizabeth A. Sackler, the arts patron known for her contributions to the Brooklyn Museum. The apartment, which has a large terrace, had an asking price of $10.5 million. Mr. Weill, 73, stepped down as the chairman of
title: BIG DEAL; My Neighbor, My Buyer

author: This column about the local economy appears every other week. E-mail address: homefront@nytimes.com.
body: MICHELLE LEWIS had cooked some chickens and had broken the meat into small pieces. Now she was cutting fresh squash, broccoli, cauliflower, carrots and celery into even smaller pieces, which she would briefly boil. She would later mix everything together, along with safflower oil, flaxseed oil, coconut oil, brown rice and hard-boiled eggs and their
title: HOME FRONT; The Latest Dish, for Four-Legged Friends

body: For the last four decades, the predominantly black population of central Brooklyn has been represented in Washington by one of its own, a tradition that dates to the 1968 victory of Shirley Chisholm, the first black woman elected to Congress. But now, in a district whose boundaries were drawn to strengthen black voting power, residents are locked
title: In Shirley Chisholm's Brooklyn, Rancor Over White Candidacy

body: WHEN Charlie Sahadi was growing up in Bay Ridge, Brooklyn, in the 1950's, other neighborhood children set up lemonade stands on hot days. Charlie and his brother sold rose- and violet-flavored drinks at the end of their driveway instead. Their great-uncle was Ibrahim Sahadi, who came to New York from the fertile Bekaa Valley in Lebanon, and began
title: SUMMER DRINKS; The World's Cups

body: CARMINE CINCOTTA, 53, was in his usual position at the back of Jim and Andy's, a narrow slip of a produce store on Court Street along the Boerum Hill-Cobble Hill fault line. A folded copy of a newspaper rested on a box of kiwis in front of him, open to the crossword. ''Fielding novel?'' he grunted, eyes peering over the tops of his black spectacles
title: CITY PEOPLE; Family Matters on Court Street

title: For Brooklyn's Beacon, The Luxe Life

title: STATE OF THE UNIONS; Ayun Halliday and Greg Kotis -- Featured in Vows, Nov. 12, 1995

title: LIVING IN/Cobble Hill, Brooklyn; A Timeless Neighborhood Grows Even More Popular

body: NOTHING excites a restaurant hound like the special dish that customers will never taste. Maybe it's the fritters a chef fries up only for friends, or the mole the Oaxacan line cooks serve for staff meals. Or maybe it's the McBruschetta. Amid a string of exchanges on an Internet message board for McDonald's employees around the world at
title: Fast-Food Chefs, Having It Their Way

body: An accomplished fund-raiser for New York City's public schools has been picked as the president of the corporation devoted to the reinvention of Governors Island, a $1 gift to the city and state whose future has been mulled over for three years with little to show for the effort. title: A New Motivator for Governors Island

Rockefeller that the state was shortchanging its cities, I applaud Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg's recently found hard-line stance. That report established that the Legislature had systematically stolen money from cities' shares of
title: Real Estate Taxes And City Schools

title: Metro Matters; Schools Strike A Nerve. Parents Yell.

body: The window grate was down last week at American Liberty Bail Bonds, on Atlantic Avenue in Brooklyn, and it looked as if it had been down for a while. The sign out front was intact, but the storefront, across from the vacant Brooklyn House of Detention on the edge of Boerum Hill, was now home to jumbled stacks of chairs, a dusty dryer and a chunk of
title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: DOWNTOWN BROOKLYN; Jailhouse Blues? On the Contrary

body: The Brooklyn House of Detention, bounded by Atlantic Avenue and the criminal courts building, is apparently headed into a mixed-use future. Soon, it will house not only inmates and jail cells, but also, in a vision endorsed by the mayor, a 24,000-square-foot strip mall on the street level. The biggest question may now be which businesses the
title: Prisoners Up Above, 'Nifty-Gifties' Down Below

body: By almost any measure, the Brooklyn House of Detention, 10 stories of razor wire and wire-mesh windows in Boerum Hill, is a repellent sight. But, the city reasons, it need not be so. So, to attract people other than criminal suspects to the 760-bed jail, the Correction Department has decided to convert part of the complex into 24,000 square feet of
title: The Brooklyn House of Detention, Seen as a Jail With Retail

body: Just a couple of steps from the culinary melting pot that Smith Street in Boerum Hill, Brooklyn, has become, there is Hanco's, a bright little Vietnamese sandwich shop with a counter and a few tables. Hanco Tang, the owner, below, sells the sandwiches, called banh mi, on warm, plump, crusty little baguettes ($4.25). The classic combines spiced
title: FOOD STUFF; From Vietnam to Boerum Hill

body: The number of inmates in New York City jails has been rising faster than correction officials had anticipated, by 9 percent since Jan. 1, leaving the jails at close to their current capacity. It is not clear why it it is happening, but if the trend continues, the City Correction Department will need to reopen the Brooklyn House of Detention,
title: City Inmate Population Up; Brooklyn Jail May Reopen

title: THE HUNT; Learning to Live in a (Slightly) Larger Space

body: IN the mid-1990's, Chris Piazza would walk the streets of Brooklyn looking for boarded-up carriage houses. ''I'd take down their addresses,'' she said, ''look up the tax records and write to the owners to see if they wanted to sell.'' She didn't hit pay dirt, so she and her husband at the time decided to move from Prospect Heights to Yonkers. It
title: HABITATS/Boerum Hill, Brooklyn; Her Carriage House Is a Stable for Her Art

body: AT 168th Street and Nelson Avenue in the South Bronx, you can look 134 blocks downtown and see the upper third of the Empire State Building pop up unexpectedly like a silvery beacon. So close to Manhattan, and yet so far away. On that corner, though, the consequences of Manhattan's wealth are beginning to be felt. It is the site of the first
title: So Close

body: HAS lifestyle finally toppled location from the top of the real estate lexicon? It is hard to figure out where the condos are. The ad features a photo of six leggy women in evening
title: BIG DEAL; The New 'L' Word

body: A 21-year-old Bronx woman was fatally shot early yesterday in front of her apartment building, the police said, and the man wanted for questioning in her death shot and killed himself hours later in Queens. In two unrelated shootings, they said, the body of a 25-year-old man with a gunshot wound to the head was found in Queens, and a 17-year-old
title: Man, Woman and Boy Are Killed in Separate Shootings in City

body: BAD enough that we have hate crime. But now we have to contend with hat crime as well. Let's say that you want to take your baseball cap or fedora (also known as a real hat), paint something on it and sell it on New York streets as artwork. You can't do that. At least you can't do it without first getting a license from the city. Otherwise, you are
title: NYC; Off With Their Hats!

title: CRITIC'S NOTEBOOK; Creeping Up On Diners: Stealth Charges

title: Pension Issue Persists After the Transit Strike
